page.title: 16Archaeology on Papa Stour.
page.content: Papa Stour (rhymes with cure) comes from the Norse "{Papa ey Storr}" which means the big island of the priests, (there is also a Papa Little). The island has been inhabited since the stone-age and archaeological remains are abundant.There are chambered cairns and broch sites as well as the more recent remains of an 18th century leper colony and 19th. century horizontal water mills. The discovery of an ancient law suite prompted Dr.B.Crawford to invest igate old place names,in an attempt to pinpoint the site of Duke Haakon's palace(he later became king of Norway) Since then, digging has gone on at the most likely site i.e.Biggins (old name{Nordaflo"}).The foundations of a substantial building have yielded some textiles and a lot of medieval pottery _but as yet nothing conclusive.
